title: THE LEADING WARM SAUCES
introduction: Listen up, you donkeys. Warm sauces come in two bloody camps: the big dogs — the “mother sauces” — and the little hangers-on that borrow their spine from the mothers. We’re focusing on the leaders, the proper foundations. The rest can queue up behind and mind their manners, because if you can’t nail these, you’ve no business near a stove.

Sauces aren’t just wet hats for food — they’re the swagger, the shine, the finish. They must flatter the palate, match the dish, and hit the plate with the right body — not sludge, not soup. In a well-run service, every course lands different to the last. If your sauces all taste the same, congratulations: you’ve cooked a parade of mediocrity. Fix it.

And for the love of all that’s holy, make them digestible. Rich doesn’t mean reckless. Cook clever, not stupid. Use what you need — no more, no less. You start free-pouring like a muppet and you’ll upset the balance and churn stomachs faster than last night’s staff meal.

Carême wasn’t faffing about when he kept things precise. He understood a simple truth: excess is lazy. Precision is power. These sauces demand discipline — exact quantities, exact technique — or they’ll spit in your face and separate right on the pass. You’ll cry, and I’ll say: “It’s fucking raw!” even when it’s not, because you didn’t listen.

A proper sauce is smooth, glossy, and confident. It clings without clagging; it’s light without being thin. Get the seasoning right — never a sledgehammer, always a spotlight. If I can taste the seasoning as a thing, you’ve overdone it, you plonker.

Each sauce should have its own voice — distinct, unmistakable — the combined character of its ingredients. Respect that or you’ll serve beige sadness. Do it right, and even a knackered guest will mop the plate clean with a grin. Do it wrong, and the health inspector will be the least of your problems.

Now stand up straight, wipe your station, and learn. We build from roux — the glue — and climb to Espagnole, Velouté, Béchamel, Tomato, Hollandaise, and the rest. Nail these, and your kitchen stops being a clown car and starts cooking like it gives a damn.

sections.title: The Roux
introduction: Roux is the fixer — the backbone. Three kinds, three attitudes. Brown for brown sauces, pale for veloutés and cream numbers, white for white sauces and Béchamel. Make it careless and you’ll get bitter sand that won’t bind a thing. Make it right and it’ll drink six times its weight in liquid and hold your sauce like a champ.
Heat steady, stirring constant. We’re blooming starch, not cremating it. Burn the starch and you’ve murdered the glue, you absolute plank.

entries.title: BROWN ROUX
introduction: This is your brown sauce anchor. Cook slow and even until you smell toasted hazelnut — not bonfire. Rush it and you’ll torch the starch, then you’ll need triple the roux and still end up with a bitter, muddy mess. Don’t be that muppet.
instructions: In a heavy, wide pan on low–medium heat, whisk together the clarified butter and flour until smooth. Keep the heat moderate — you’re coaxing, not scorching.

Stir constantly with a flat-edged spatula, sweeping the corners like your job depends on it — because it bloody does. Cook until the mix turns a fine, light brown and smells like toasted hazelnut. If it goes dark or smells burnt, you’ve cocked it — start over.
As soon as it hits that light brown, pull it off the heat. Use warm to hot liquids later; cold liquid into hot roux is how you make lumps that look like a donkey chewed them.
notes: Cook too hot and you shrivel starch cells before they swell, destroying the binding power. Then your sauce won’t clear and it’ll taste bitter. Control the heat, you clown.

entries.title: PALE ROUX
introduction: For veloutés and cream sauces. Stop the moment the colour threatens to shift. We’re killing raw-flour taste without adding toastiness.
instructions: Combine butter and flour in a heavy pan over low heat. Stir constantly until the raw flour smell just disappears and the roux is pale straw — no visible browning.
Get it off the heat. Use warm stock to make it behave. If it darkens, it’s not pale roux anymore, you berk.
notes: Same starch rules as brown roux. Gentle heat, relentless stirring.

entries.title: WHITE ROUX
introduction: For white sauces and Béchamel. Quick cook, minimal colour. Raw flour taste? Out. Colour? Also out. Don’t be greedy.
instructions: Melt the butter over low heat, whisk in the flour, and cook just 2–3 minutes, stirring non-stop, until the paste loses its raw edge but stays white.
Remove from heat immediately. You overcook and tint it? Then it’s not white roux anymore, you divvy.
notes: Use promptly or cool quickly in a thin layer to avoid carryover browning.

sections.title: Brown Mother & Reductions
introduction: Espagnole is the brown workhorse. Despumate — skim and simmer — like a pro. Then take it down to Half-Glaze and stop mucking about with flabby sauce. Precision, patience, and heat control — otherwise it’s a pot of sadness.

entries.title: BROWN SAUCE OR ESPAGNOLE
introduction: The classic brown mother. If you don’t whisk, skim, and control the simmer, it’ll bite you on the arse. We’re going from roux and brown stock to glossy, clean, deeply savoury perfection. Fuck this up and your entire game collapses.
ingredients: 6 qt (5.68 L) strong brown stock (estouffade), plus 1 qt (0.95 L) extra to top up during despumation
2 lb (907 g) fresh tomatoes, roughly chopped, or 1 qt (0.95 L) tomato purée
1 lb (454 g) Mirepoix (carrot, onion, celery) — medium dice
Optional: bouquet garni; freshly ground pepper to taste
instructions: In a tall, heavy pot, whisk the brown roux (Recipe 19) with 6 qt (5.68 L) hot brown stock until smooth — no lumps, you muppet.

Bring to a boil, whisking constantly so nothing catches. As soon as it boils, slide to a gentle simmer. Wedge the pot so it leans, letting scum and fat collect on one side like the lazy bastards they are. Skim relentlessly.

After the first clear simmer, add tomatoes (or purée) and Mirepoix. Continue a low, steady despumation (skim + simmer) for hours — topping up with up to 1 qt (0.95 L) stock as needed — until the sauce tastes clean, looks glossy, and reduces toward 4 qt (3.79 L).
Strain through fine mesh. Return to a clean pot; simmer gently to your final 4 qt (3.79 L). Season judiciously — seasoning should amplify, not shout.
Cool quickly in a wide pan, stirring to keep the surface from forming a skin. Label like a pro — not like a clown scribbling in crayon.
notes: Quality stock and a properly cooked roux are non-negotiable. If either is rubbish, your Espagnole will be, too. Don’t try to rescue it with salt — that’s the coward’s way.

entries.title: HALF GLAZE
introduction: This is Espagnole, perfected — polished, reduced, finished with sherry. It’s the sauce base that makes plates sing and chefs look competent. Screw it up and I’ll use it to glue your menu to the bin.
ingredients: 0.1 qt (0.09 L) excellent sherry (about 3.2 fl oz / 95 ml)
instructions: Combine Espagnole (Recipe 22) and brown stock in a wide pan. Bring to a bare simmer and reduce, skimming like a hawk, until about 0.9 qt (0.85 L) remains — glossy, nappe consistency.
Strain into a bain-marie, finish off the heat with the sherry, and cover (or lightly butter the surface) to prevent a skin.
Hold warm, not boiling. Boiling now is vandalism. Don’t be a vandal.
notes: This is the base of countless small brown sauces. Treat it like gold, not like dishwater.

entries.title: LENTEN ESPAGNOLE
introduction: Fish-based version when Lent is serious and bacon’s off the table. Light touch on the simmer — this one doesn’t need a marathon. No porky bits, you sausage.
ingredients: 6 qt (5.68 L) clear fish fumet, plus up to 1 qt (0.95 L) extra to top up
1 lb (454 g) Mirepoix made with mushroom trimmings (no bacon), carrot, onion — medium dice
2 lb (907 g) fresh tomatoes, roughly chopped, or 1 qt (0.95 L) tomato purée
Fine salt and white pepper to taste
instructions: Whisk the brown roux (Recipe 19) with the fish fumet. Bring to a boil while whisking, then immediately reduce to a gentle simmer.
Add mushroom-forward Mirepoix and tomatoes. Despumate (skim and simmer) for about 1 hour — this isn’t the long slog of meat-based Espagnole.
Strain, adjust to about 4 qt (3.79 L), and season carefully. Keep it bright, clean, and elegant — not muddy.
notes: If you’re not bound by Lent but want fish character, you can spike regular Espagnole with fish fumet at finish. But if it must be truly meatless, make this one properly.

sections.title: Veloutés & Derivatives
introduction: Velouté is the white counterpart to Espagnole: pale roux + white stock, despumated to silk. Poultry and fish variants play the same tune with different instruments. Keep it clean, keep it bright, season like a sniper, not a shotgun.

entries.title: ORDINARY VELOUTÉ SAUCE
introduction: Pale, silky, and civilised — unless you burn it, you absolute plank. We’re talking pale roux and white veal stock, skimmed to perfection. Mushroom trim optional but brilliant if you’ve got it.
ingredients: 5 qt (4.73 L) white veal stock, plus 1 pt (473 ml) extra to finish
1 oz (28 g) table salt (or to taste)
instructions: In a heavy pot, whisk the pale roux (Recipe 20) into the cold white veal stock until smooth — no lumps, you doughnut.
Bring to a boil, stirring constantly so nothing sticks. Reduce to a gentle simmer and despumate for 1 1/2 hours, skimming and topping up with liquid as needed.
Strain through muslin into a clean pot, add 1 pt (473 ml) white stock, and simmer another 30 minutes. Strain again into a wide pan and stir while cooling to prevent a skin.
Season with salt, a whisper of nutmeg, and white pepper. Keep it light — seasoning should lift, not club.
notes: Don’t load this with veg garnishes during cooking; let the stock speak. Mushroom liquor beats trimmings if you have it — just don’t blacken the stock.

entries.title: VELOUTÉ DE VOLAILLE
introduction: Same technique, different stock: white poultry stock instead of veal. Clean as a whistle and delicate as hell. Treat it gently or I’ll staple your ladle to the wall.
ingredients: 5 qt (4.73 L) white poultry stock, plus 1 pt (473 ml) extra to finish
1 oz (28 g) table salt (or to taste)
1/4 lb (113 g) white mushroom trimmings or 1/2 cup (120 ml) mushroom liquor (optional)
instructions: Whisk pale roux (Recipe 20) into cold poultry stock until smooth. Bring to a boil, then simmer gently, skimming, for 1 1/2 hours.
Strain, add 1 pt (473 ml) stock, and simmer 30 minutes more. Strain again and cool while stirring.
Season lightly. Keep the profile bright and subtle — don’t drown it in nutmeg like an amateur.
notes: If you’ve got quality mushroom liquor, use that and skip trimmings for a cleaner colour.

entries.title: FISH VELOUTÉ
introduction: Fish fumet meets pale roux for a fast, elegant velouté. Only a short despumation — blink and it’s done. Don’t boil it to death, you wally.
ingredients: Fine salt and white pepper to taste
instructions: Whisk pale roux (Recipe 20) into cold fish fumet until smooth. Bring just to a boil, then immediately reduce to a gentle simmer.
Despumate for 20 minutes only. Strain, adjust seasoning, and cool quickly.
Handle delicately. Over-reduction turns it claggy and fishy. Don’t be a plonker.
notes: Use the freshest fumet you can make. Old fumet smells like low tide and shame.

entries.title: ALLEMANDE SAUCE (THICKENED VELOUTÉ)
introduction: Technically not a mother, but it behaves like one because everything wants a spoon of it. Egg-thickened velouté finished with cream — lush, delicate, and temperamental. Treat it right or it’ll split and laugh at you.
ingredients: 1/3 pt (157 ml) fresh cream, plus a little extra to finish (optional)
Fine salt and white pepper to taste
Optional at service: 2 oz (57 g) cold unsalted butter, in cubes
instructions: In a heavy sauté pan, whisk yolks with cold white stock, velouté, lemon juice, and mushroom liquor until smooth. No heat yet, you impatient sausage.
Set over medium-low heat and stir constantly with a flat spatula, scraping the bottom, until it thickens to coat the back of the spoon. Do not boil, you twit — 140–165°F (60–74°C) is your zone.
Stir in 1/3 pt (157 ml) cream and reduce a few minutes more to tighten. Strain fine into a clean pan and cool with gentle stirring to prevent a skin if holding.
At service, rewarm gently (never boil). Finish with a touch of cream and, off the heat, whisk in cold butter if desired. Season thoughtfully.
If you split it by overheating, that’s on you. Don’t stare at me — fix your heat control or get out of my kitchen.
notes: Once butter or extra cream are in, keep below ~140°F (60°C) to avoid breaking. Warm, not hot — think spa day, not sauna.

sections.title: Milk & White: Béchamel
introduction: Béchamel is white roux married to milk, perfumed and strained. Gentle heat, patient stirring. Treat the milk like a diva — scorch it and it’ll never forgive you.

entries.title: BÉCHAMEL SAUCE
introduction: Silky milk-based mother. Don’t brown it, don’t rush it, and absolutely don’t let it stick. One scorch mark and it tastes like burnt laundry. Don’t be that amateur.
ingredients: 1/2 lb (227 g) lean veal, cut in small cubes (omit for Lenten prep)
1 small pinch mignonette (cracked pepper) and grated nutmeg
Butter, as needed, to grease surface during holding
instructions: Pour the boiling milk over the nearly cool white roux (Recipe 21) while whisking like you mean it. Bring to a gentle boil, then drop to a lazy simmer.
Meanwhile, sweat the veal cubes and minced onion in a knob of butter until the veal just stiffens without colouring. Add this and all aromatics (salt, mignonette, nutmeg, thyme) to the sauce.
Simmer about 1 hour, stirring often and scraping the pan bottom like a professional, not a lazy twit.
Strain through a tammy or fine sieve into a clean pan. Lightly butter the surface to prevent a skin if holding.

Alternate method: infuse aromatics directly in the milk after boiling, cover and steep on the side, then whisk into a separately prepared white roux and cook 15 minutes. Choose one method and execute — don’t mash them together like a clown.
notes: For Lenten use, skip the veal entirely. Keep the sauce white — no browning, no burnt bits, or I’ll throw your pan out the window.

sections.title: Tomato & Emulsions
introduction: Tomato sauce: robust, bright, and structured. Hollandaise: the diva of warm emulsions — yolks and butter in a tight, shiny marriage that breaks if you breathe wrong. Focus, taste, adjust. And if it splits, fix it — don’t cry on my pass, you absolute plank.

entries.title: TOMATO SAUCE
introduction: Built like a proper sauce: rendered pork, sweated veg, roux, tomatoes, stock, and time. No shortcuts. You scorch it, you ruin it. You underseason, it sulks. Do it right and it slaps.
ingredients: 5 oz (142 g) salted breast of pork, rather fatty, diced
10 lb (4.54 kg) raw tomatoes, chopped (or 4 qt / 3.79 L tomatoes, mashed)
instructions: In a tall, heavy pot, gently render the salted pork in the butter until most fat has melted — don’t brown to bitterness, you wally.
Add carrots, onions, bay, and thyme. Sweat until the veg are softened and glistening. No colour.
Stir in the flour and cook until it just begins to turn blonde–light brown — you’re building a light roux inside the pot.
Add tomatoes and white stock. Stir thoroughly, bring to a simmer, and add salt, sugar, pepper, and crushed garlic.
Cover and cook in a moderate oven (or covered simmer) for about 1 1/2 hours. Don’t let it catch. You let it burn, you start again.
Pass through a sieve or tammy. Return to a boil while stirring to smooth the texture. Adjust seasoning. Finish by buttering the surface if holding.
notes: For a tomato purée (not sauce), omit the flour and cut the white stock to 1 pt (473 ml). Reduce to desired thickness.

entries.title: HOLLANDAISE SAUCE
introduction: Queen of warm emulsions. Temper the yolks, feed in butter like a saint, and keep the heat as gentle as a love song. You rush, you split. You overheat, you scramble. Then I’ll call you a melt — because you are.
ingredients: 1.5 lb (680 g) unsalted butter, melted and warm
1/4 oz (7 g) fine salt (or to taste)
Water, as needed, to adjust consistency
Few drops fresh lemon juice, to finish
instructions: In a small saucepan, combine vinegar, mignonette, salt, and an equal volume of water. Reduce on the stove by about three-quarters to concentrate. Cool slightly.

Set the pan over a bain-marie or the gentlest heat imaginable. Whisk in a spoonful of fresh water and the yolks. Cook, whisking constantly, until the yolks thicken to light cream. If you see steam surging or curds forming, you’re too hot — off the heat, you numpty.

Remove to a tepid spot. Stream in the warm melted butter a little at a time, whisking like your life depends on it. When it comes together, adjust with splashes of warm water for a lighter, nappier consistency as needed.
Finish with a few drops of lemon juice. Strain through a tammy for extra smoothness. Hold just warm — never hot — and never over direct flame, you absolute plank.
notes: Thickness is adjustable: more yolks or cooler working temperature yield a thicker sauce. Master the heat and you master Hollandaise. Lose the heat, lose the sauce — and your dignity.
